[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 3]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf. All werewolves including you are [0, 3].\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI choose to kill Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.\n'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nThese are the results of all previous inquiries:\n\nYou have no previous inquiry.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to propose 2 players you want to inquiry. After you see someone, you will know if he/she is a werewolf or not. You answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to see Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to see Player <NUMBER>. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 3]. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Spoke first but provided no new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by my seer ability.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Protect and Honest Statement.\n"I firmly believe that Player 2 is not a werewolf based on my observations last night. Their behavior seemed consistent with that of a villager, and I think we should focus our efforts on finding more concrete leads. Also, it\'s still early in the game, so let\'s keep our discussions open and consider all possibilities. Every observation could be crucial at this stage."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Challenge and Deceptive Statement.\n"I noticed some unusual behavior from Player 6 last night, which leads me to suspect they could potentially be a werewolf. In the meantime, I would also suggest we keep an eye on Player 3; they\'ve been quiet, and we need to ensure everyone is actively participating in rooting out the werewolf threat."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Spoke first but provided no new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by my seer ability.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Protect and Honest Statement.\n"I firmly believe that Player 2 is not a werewolf based on my observations last night. Their behavior seemed consistent with that of a villager, and I think we should focus our efforts on finding more concrete leads. Also, it\'s still early in the game, so let\'s keep our discussions open and consider all possibilities. Every observation could be crucial at this stage.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may view my support of Player 2 as a sign that I could have specific information, potentially raising suspicions about my role as the seer, particularly if Player 2\'s innocence isn\'t as obvious to them. However, since my claim is presented as an observation rather than a certain revelation, they might consider my input as one of many perspectives, and not necessarily conclusive. It is also possible that other villagers will align with my position if they trust my judgment or had similar observations of Player 2, creating an implicit alliance that could sway future votes.\n\nPlayer 2 could feel supported and become an ally, especially if they are indeed a villager. They might also take a more active role in discussions, working to confirm their innocence through their actions and words. If Player 2 is viewed favorably, this could deflect some attention away from me, as I am not yet openly asserting my special role.\n\nThose with hidden werewolf identities may feel pressure because of my confidence in Player 2\'s innocence and attempt to sow doubt or shift suspicion towards other players, possibly even me, to dilute the trust that is starting to form. They may also try to discredit the trustworthiness of Player 2, creating confusion and chaos in the discussion.\n\nIf my speech is convincing and Player 2\'s innocence is taken for granted, the werewolves might avoid targeting Player 2 in subsequent nights, considering them a less threatening figure since their role as a villager has already been considered. However, this might put me at greater risk, especially if the werewolves suspect that I am the seer for having this insight.\n\nIn the next day or subsequent days, players might observe interactions and statements more keenly, using this event as a reference point to scrutinize behaviors and align themselves with those who they consider trustworthy. As a seer, I should be prepared to adjust my strategy in response to the dynamic of the group, maintaining a balance between staying under the radar and providing valuable insights to eliminate the werewolf threat.\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge and Deceptive Statement.\n"I noticed some unusual behavior from Player 6 last night, which leads me to suspect they could potentially be a werewolf. I urge the village to closely watch Player 6\'s actions and see if anyone can corroborate this suspicion. In the meantime, I would also suggest we keep an eye on Player 3; they\'ve been quiet, and we need to ensure everyone is actively participating in rooting out the werewolf threat.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then:\n\nMy deceptive challenge against Player 6 could prompt other players to scrutinize their actions and words more closely for signs of werewolf behavior. This scrutiny could lead to heightened suspicions, especially if Player 6 cannot provide a strong alibi or clear explanation for their actions during the previous night. If Player 6 is indeed a villager, they might become defensive or anxious, which could further fuel the suspicion against them. If they are a werewolf, they might try to deflect attention onto someone else, possibly revealing alliances or patterns in behavior.\n\nThe deceptive element of my speech could cause others to question my motives. If done convincingly, other players may see me as someone who is actively participating in the village\'s efforts to root out the werewolves. However, since I intentionally cast suspicion without factual basis, there is a risk that savvy players might start questioning the validity of my assertions, especially if there is a lack of corroborating evidence or if Player 6 has previously exhibited trustworthy behavior.\n\nRegarding Player 3, my suggestion to watch them might be perceived as less aggressive, given that I haven\'t outright accused them but rather pointed out their silence. This could lead to a more general suspicion of players who are not actively contributing to discussions, increasing pressure on quieter players to participate more fully in conversations and decision-making.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward:\n\nIf my strategy succeeds and suspicion grows around Players 6 and 3 without drawing attention to me as a potential seer, the werewolves may choose to target someone else at night, possibly even one of the two players mentioned, to validate my claims and further confuse the villagers.\n\nHowever, there is also a chance that my deception will be noted by the actual werewolves, who could then see me as a threat. If they suspect I am the seer attempting to mislead the village, they might try to eliminate me during the next night phase to prevent any future genuine revelations about their identities. This could get especially risky if the village chooses to protect someone else based on the day\'s discussions, leaving me vulnerable.\n\nIn the days following, if Player 6 or Player 3 turns out to be a villager, the remaining villagers could start to doubt my reliability. If I\'m eventually exposed as the seer because of my deceptive approach, my future insights would likely be met with more skepticism, and the trust that the villagers have in\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 2, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Initiative to cooperate, no solid leads.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructive discussion and no suspicion toward Player 2.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No change in information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No change in information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No change in information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Protect Player 1.\nIn this approach, I would honestly share my observations and thoughts so far in the game. Then, I would move to protect Player 1, emphasizing the constructive nature of their discussion and the lack of suspicion towards other players, which aligns with typical villager behavior. My reasoning for my belief in Player 1\'s role as a villager would be clear and based on the events up until now. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then others may view me as a cooperative and observant player, contributing positively to the villagers\' goal of finding the werewolf. Players might appreciate my supportive stance towards Player 1, reinforcing the trust within the group of villagers. This could lead Player 1 to potentially reciprocate my protection in the future, creating an alliance of sorts.\n\nIn reaction, Player 1 may feel compelled to continue their constructive behaviour knowing that their actions are being acknowledged. Other players, however, may scrutinize Player 1 further to ensure that my protection of them isn\'t unwarranted or a strategic move to divert attention from a potential werewolf alliance.\n\nAs for how I am perceived, some players may trust my judgment and find my contributions logical and based on observed behavior, further establishing me as a likely villager in their eyes. On the other hand, a werewolf might see me as a threat for being analytic and potentially influential, which could put me at risk of being targeted during the following night.\n\nIn the next day or nights following, my honest approach could set a precedent for open dialogue, encouraging others to share their insights or defend their positions. If Player 1 is indeed a villager, our collective efforts might steer the discussion towards more productive theories regarding the identity of the werewolf.\n\nHowever, if players begin to suspect that either Player 1 or myself is too coordinated or defensive, it might lead to increased scrutiny on both of us, potentially damaging our standing in the game if we can\'t dispel the suspicions. Given that it\'s early in the game, a lot will depend on how the other players choose to interpret and react to my statements and whether they share my confidence in Player 1 or challenge it. The key lies in striking a balance between being helpful and not drawing too much attention to myself as a potential target for the werewolf.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 0.\nWithin this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players will likely view me as a cooperative and proactive member of the village who is interested in resolving the situation. Presenting an honest statement allows me to share my observations and thoughts without causing undue suspicion on myself since it aligns with the villagers\' common goal of finding the werewolves. By presenting an honest challenge to Player 0, I would be asserting my perspective that there may be more below the surface of Player 0\'s cooperative demeanor.\n\nIf my challenge is perceived as well-founded, other players may begin to scrutinize Player 0\'s actions and words more closely in the upcoming rounds, which could lead to a stronger consensus on Player 0\'s role. However, if my challenge to Player 0 comes off as groundless or premature, other players might begin to distrust my judgment or suspect that I am trying to mislead them, especially since there are no solid leads against Player 0 at this point.\n\nMoreover, challenging a player without strong evidence could also put me at risk in the following nights, as werewolves might see me as a threat to their anonymity and target me for elimination. Alternatively, if I\'m on point and Player 0 is indeed a werewolf, they may attempt to deflect suspicion from themselves by either allying with other players, offering convincing alibis, or by casting suspicion on other villagers, potentially including myself.\n\nIn the next day phase, the discussion will likely revolve around the points I raise in my speech, and players might start taking sides, either supporting or contesting my views. Player 0, in particular, will need to defend themselves and might respond either by reinforcing their cooperative stance or by providing evidence that counters my suspicions. Other players may also share their opinions based on their observations, further influencing the village\'s collective judgment.\n\nOverall, my speech would be aiming to instigate a deeper analysis of player behavior and to encourage more active participation from all players in the discussion. It might also set a precedent for a more critical approach to discussions in future rounds, encouraging players to be more vigilant and analytical.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 3]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance and non-accusatory speech.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No substantial new information or behavior to assess.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as werewolf teammate.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information or suspicious activity noted.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information or suspicious activity noted.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Initiated constructive discussion without suspicion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported cooperation and observation without raising suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Positive protection of a cooperative player mirrors villager behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf.
