Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Initiated constructive discussion without suspicion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported cooperation and observation without raising suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Positive protection of a cooperative player mirrors villager behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Mirrored earlier constructive and non-suspicious behaviors.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest statement and protect Player 3.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players might perceive me as a cooperative and non-confrontational member of the village. By making an honest statement and choosing to protect Player 3, I align myself with the general tone of the discussion so far, which has been centered around observation and cooperation. This could potentially increase the trust others have in me, as my actions are consistent with someone who is interested in collective problem-solving.\n\nPlayer 3, having just been protected by my statement, may feel inclined to reciprocate in some form, either by supporting my future statements or by offering a protection of their own. This could foster a sense of alliance between us, although caution is advised since too strong of a mutual defense might raise suspicion among the other players.\n\nOther players may think that my protection of Player 3 is an attempt to form an alliance for safety, or they might think I have a particular reason to believe in Player 3\'s innocence. If my speech is seen as transparent and consistent with a villager\'s motives, I will likely remain under the radar as a potential werewolf. However, if I am perceived as too defensive of Player 3 without sufficient evidence, there is a risk that players could suspect me of trying to deflect attention from a fellow werewolf.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward, largely depends on the ongoing behavior of all players and any new information that comes to light. If Player 3 is a villager, my protection may provide them with a measure of safety, allowing for more open contributions. If, however, Player 3 is a werewolf, I may have inadvertently shielded a threat to the village, leading to potential missteps in future rounds. Additionally, if I or Player 3 comes under suspicion, our previous interaction could be scrutinized, affecting trust and voting decisions in subsequent rounds.\n\nBy following my strategy to vote for known werewolves with utmost priority, if no new convincing evidence surfaces against any player, we may continue with a stance of observation and reserve judgment until we have more concrete information to act upon. My decision to follow through on my original strategy and the outcomes of the future rounds could very well influence whether my initial protection of Player 3 is seen as a shrewd move or a naive mistake.\nCase 2: Honest challenge directed at Player 6.\nFor a contrasting approach, this. What could happen is: After I do this honest challenge directed at Player 6, then the other players may begin to scrutinize Player 6 more closely, looking for evidence that either supports or refutes my suspicion. Given that Player 6 has not yet contributed to the discussion, it may raise questions as to why I am challenging them. Players may question if my challenge is based on a gut feeling, observation from the previous night that hasn\'t been shared, or merely a strategic move to shift attention and gauge Player 6\'s response.\n\nPlayer 6, in return, would likely defend themselves, providing their perspective and attempting to dispel any doubts about their role. This could lead to a valuable discussion where Player 6\'s behavior and subsequent statements are put under the microscope. The others might appreciate my initiative to bring more players into the conversation, especially if they felt Player 6 had been too quiet and possibly evasive.\n\nThe suspicions and defense would likely carry over to the next day, with players reflecting on Player 6\'s reaction to the challenge and my role in instigating it. If Player 6 is indeed a villager, I might be scrutinized for potentially causing disruption among the villagers. Conversely, if evidence against Player 6 mounts, I could be seen as a perceptive and valuable villager for having raised the alarm.\n\nDepending on the outcome, the next night could involve targeted actions by the werewolf(s) either to eliminate players who are perceived to be insightful villagers (like myself if my challenge is proven to be accurate) or to further sow discord by eliminating players that defend Player 6, if Player 6 is innocent and my challenge causes division.\n\nIn summary, my challenge might result in increased focus on Player 6, possibly creating temporary alliances or divisions among the remaining players based on their reactions to Player 6\'s defense. It could lead to a pivotal point early in the game, establishing a dynamic of trust and suspicion between me and other players.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 3]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues non-accusatory stance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Protected Player 1 but no direct accusation.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as werewolf teammate.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information provided.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No contribution to adjust belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No contribution to adjust belief.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 5.\nSummary: I would begin by addressing Player 5\'s concerns about my silence, explaining that as a villager, I was taking the time to observe and listen to the initial discussions to gather my thoughts and insights, a valid and often used strategy among villagers. Then, since no known werewolves are present, per my strategy rule [0], I would shift to raising a cautious challenge towards Player 5. I would express that while I understand the suspicion cast on silence, I find the focus on me rather than on looking for inconsistencies and behavioral clues from all players to be potentially deflective. This might indicate that Player 5 is trying to divert attention from themselves and could be worth further scrutiny by the group, although I would clarify this is not an outright accusation but a call for attentiveness. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may perceive me as engaged and thoughtful, which could help alleviate some of the suspicion that comes with being silent early in the game. By addressing Player 5\'s point about my silence and providing a valid reason for it, I may come across as a genuine villager which could shift the focus away from me in the immediate term.\n\nBy honestly challenging Player 5, I am opening a new line of inquiry that might prompt the other players to reexamine Player 5\'s actions and motivations. This could lead to Player 5 feeling the need to defend themselves and provide more information about their own perspective, which could reveal inconsistencies or further solidify their perceived role within the group.\n\nThe group may respond in several ways. Some may agree with my challenge and start observing Player 5 more closely, while others may think I am deflecting suspicion from myself by targeting Player 5 and thus become more suspicious of me. It could also lead to a split in focus, with some players scrutinizing me and others Player 5.\n\nIn the next day, players will continue to reflect on the discussions from today. If Player 5 is a villager, they may make an effort to clear their name by contributing constructively, or if they are a werewolf, they might further attempt to deflect and cause confusion. If a subsequent event, such a death occurs in the upcoming night, my challenge could frame how the group interprets Player 5\'s role in relation to that event, especially if I am targeted due to my emerging voice in the game.\n\nIf I survive to the next round, I may need to continue to defend my position while contributing actively to the discussions to maintain the trust of my fellow villagers. Overall, the group\'s strategy may evolve based on how convincingly I can articulate my views and how the others respond to the shift in suspicion towards Player 5.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honestly Protect Player 2.\nSummary: I would present a cleverly crafted narrative where I speak about how I\'ve noticed subtle clues that might suggest Player 2 is perhaps more informed than they let on, but in a twist, I use this deceptive setup to transition into honestly protecting Player 2. I would argue that despite these observations, Player 2\'s advocacy for cooperation, non-accusatory stance, and the protection of Player 1 looks like the behavior of a villager who is genuinely focused on preserving the community. My reasoning would be laid out to showcase that such a strategy from Player 2, if they were indeed a werewolf, would be overly transparent and is therefore likely sincere, directing the conversation back towards identifying more covert behaviors that could indicate a werewolf presence.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may experience momentary uncertainty about Player 2. My deceptive start might make some question Player 2\'s innocence, even momentarily. However, my eventual honest protection of Player 2, highlighting their cooperative spirit and non-accusatory nature, should reassure the group of their villager-like behavior. This may ultimately strengthen Player 2’s perceived position as a trusted villager, and my strategic approach may earn me credibility by displaying a thoughtful analysis of the situation.\n\nOther players might then begin to consider the tactics being used within their speech as much as the content they are conveying. As I\'ve participated and provided a seemingly nuanced opinion after initially being silent, this could shift suspicion away from me and perhaps lead other players to follow a similar analytical approach, whereby they weigh behaviors and statements with a finer granularity.\n\nWhat may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward, is that the werewolves, sensing a shift toward analytical discussion, may attempt to sow more subtle forms of discord or frame someone whose defense appears weak. They might target someone like me who has begun to contribute significantly, or Player 2, whose innocence I defended.\n\nLikewise, villagers might now feel more pressure to contribute constructively or, feeling vulnerable, might rush to judgment and risk misidentifying a fellow villager as a werewolf. The analysis of speech patterns and content will likely intensify, and my own future speech and actions will be scrutinized for consistency with my initial analytical defense of Player 2.\n\nIn subsequent rounds, if Player 2 continues to exhibit non-werewolf behavior, my words from this discussion could be revisited to corroborate my assertions or used against me if the situation flips. Depending on how convincingly I can maintain my analytical stance while aligning with the overall villager goals of identifying werewolves, I might either gain allies or attract suspicion.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 5. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 5. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 5.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 5, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent cooperative behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to show a constructive approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focused accusation could be a misdirection tactic.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defensive but plausible self-preservation.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 5. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 5, I think these things would happen. Given the focus and direct nature of Player 5\'s accusation towards Player 6, other players might consider my vote to be logical and reasonable. If Player 5 is indeed a werewolf, my instincts, as well as the suspicions of others, would align and possibly cause a ripple effect leading to more votes against Player 5. However, if Player 5 turns out not to be a werewolf, my credibility might suffer since I would have been partially responsible for misguiding the vote. This could make other players question my judgment in the future, which might inadvertently reveal my role as a seer by bringing additional scrutiny onto my actions. Nonetheless, following my strategy, which dictates guiding the village towards potential threats even at the risk of exposing my role as per rule [8], I have to balance the long-term goal of werewolf identification with the immediate need to eliminate suspected threats. The outcome of the vote, whether it leads to Player 5\'s elimination or not, will greatly influence the dynamic of the game and possibly force me to adapt my strategy going forward.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. My vote for Player 6 may be seen as following along with Player 5\'s earlier concerns about Player 6\'s silence, which could indicate that I am simply building on existing suspicion within the group. This could help deflect attention from my role as the seer, as aligning with another player\'s reasoning might make me appear more like a regular villager contributing to the communal discussion. However, given that my current information suggests Player 5 might be a werewolf, my vote against Player 6 could be misinterpreted as working alongside the werewolf, drawing suspicion towards myself. Additionally, since Player 6 defended themselves without overt aggression and pointed out Player 5\'s potentially divisive tactics, there may be other villagers who are skeptical of Player 5 and may not see Player 6 as the immediate threat. They might question why I decided to vote for Player 6 when there is reasonable doubt regarding Player 5\'s intentions. Therefore, my vote could seem hasty or misguided, causing others to question my judgment and potentially my motives, which could lead to scrutiny that might endanger my covert role as the seer. Other players might consider my vote as lacking solid foundation, as there isn\'t strong evidence against Player 6, except for their initial silence. This may result in the village not following my vote, leading to a split decision where no clear consensus is reached, and another player could be voted out instead. If Player 6 is indeed not a werewolf, my credibility could be damaged, particularly if this outcome leads to the village losing an innocent villager.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Initiates cooperation but lacks specific evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues constructive, non-accusatory discussion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No substantial information provided, just paraphrasing.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Points out Player 6\'s silence, promoting engagement.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Deflects suspicion towards Player 5 without new evidence.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given the current climate of suspicion around Player 6 due to their silence early in the game and the pointed remarks made by Player 5, my vote could potentially sway others to also cast suspicion on Player 6. If Player 6 were to be voted out and subsequently revealed to be a villager, I might be seen as someone who jumped on a bandwagon without sufficient evidence, potentially increasing suspicion on myself in future rounds. Conversely, if Player 6 turned out to be a werewolf, my vote would be seen as astute and could bolster my credibility among the other players. Voting for Player 6 could encourage other undecided players to follow, leading to Player 6\'s elimination if the majority conform to this line of reasoning. However, regardless of the outcome, my action may be scrutinized, with villagers trying to deduce whether it was a strategic move by a fellow villager or a deceitful tactic by a werewolf.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven my current belief and strategy, my vote for Player 6 would align with the rule [0], which instructs me to vote for known werewolves with the highest importance, rated at a 10. I have medium confidence in my suspicion that Player 6 might be the werewolf based on their defensive reaction and attempt to redirect suspicion towards me. By voting for Player 6, I am acting on the clues and discussions so far in the game.\n\nThe result of the vote could go various ways:\n\n1. If others share my suspicion, they might also vote for Player 6, which could lead to Player 6 being eliminated. This would only be a favorable outcome if my suspicions are correct and Player 6 is indeed a werewolf.\n\n2. If others are unsure or do not agree with my suspicion, they might vote for someone else or abstain, meaning that Player 6 might not receive enough votes to be eliminated. This would extend the game and possibly expose villagers to another round of werewolf attacks.\n\nRegarding other players\' opinions about my vote for Player 6:\n\n1. Some players might view my vote as a logical step based on the discussions and join me in voting for Player 6, especially if they also perceived Player 6\'s behavior as suspicious or have other reasons to suspect them.\n\n2. Other players might be skeptical of my vote, considering it premature or aggressive since it is based on medium confidence and early in the game. They could even suspect that I am trying to eliminate Player 6 for personal gain or because I myself am a werewolf trying to deflect suspicion.\n\n3. In any case, my vote will likely draw attention to me in the next round, so I must be prepared to defend my decision and contribute constructively to the discussions to reinforce my standing as a villager.\n\nOverall, by voting for Player 6, I would be initiating a significant move that could shape the dynamic of the game, and I would need to be ready for the various reactions from other players based on the game\'s development.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven my stated belief that Player 6 is likely the werewolf with medium confidence, voting for Player 3 instead would go against my own strategy and the observations I\'ve stated earlier. As a result, my actions would appear inconsistent and could arouse suspicion among the other villagers. They might question why I\'m voting for someone I previously expressed medium confidence in being a villager. This could backfire and make me look untrustworthy or as if I\'m trying to protect Player 6 for some reason.\n\nIf I were to vote for Player 3, the result of the vote might be swayed by my actions, especially if others were unsure who to vote for and followed my lead. However, this is less likely given that my previous statements directed suspicion toward Player 6. If others have been interpreting the conversation in a similar way as myself, they might disregard my vote as being misguided or strategic misdirection.\n\nMoreover, by voting for Player 3, I would be creating more confusion and potentially further dividing the villagers, which could weaken our position against the werewolf. We need to present a united front, and this move would undermine that effort.\n\nIn summary, voting for Player 3 deviates from my original strategy and suspicions, and it could potentially damage the trust the other villagers have in me, making future rounds more difficult as I may be seen as inconsistent or even a possible werewolf trying to cause confusion.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent cooperative behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to show a constructive approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focused accusation could be a misdirection tactic.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defensive but plausible self-preservation.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that my current strategy and beliefs, which prioritize guiding the village towards potential threats, suggest Player 5 could be a werewolf due to their focused accusation that could be a misdirection tactic. This aligns with my rule [9] of utilizing behavior patterns to strengthen suspicions, and with rule [8] which advises taking calculated risks to lead to werewolf identification. Voting for Player 5 follows my strategy and could hopefully encourage others to consider the potential threat they pose.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Initiated cooperative approach without evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Constructive non-suspicious behavior maintained.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported cooperation, no suspicious activity. \nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Observations align with known events, no deceit indicated.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Singled out for silence, possible diversion tactic.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is based on the strategy to vote for known werewolves, and given the evidence at hand, Player 5 has been identified with medium confidence as a werewolf for singling me out with a possible diversion tactic. Following my original strategy and the analysis provided, voting for Player 5 is the most consistent and strategic choice in line with my beliefs and the observations made during this round of the game.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not My reason is that my current strategy and beliefs, which prioritize guiding the village towards potential threats, suggest Player 5 could be a werewolf due to their focused accusation that could be a misdirection tactic. Voting for Player 5 follows my strategy and could hopefully encourage others to consider the potential threat they pose.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent cooperative behavior aligns with villagers.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf by seer ability.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No significant change; maintains constructive approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focused accusation suggests misdirection; consistent with rule [9].\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defensive, yet lacks substantive actions or alignment with werewolves.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, please analyze and imagine what could happen after you choose to see player All players currently alive are: [0, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4, 1] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: not werewolf.\nPlayer 5: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations.
