Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that my current strategy and beliefs, which prioritize guiding the village towards potential threats, suggest Player 5 could be a werewolf due to their focused accusation that could be a misdirection tactic. This aligns with my rule [9] of utilizing behavior patterns to strengthen suspicions, and with rule [8] which advises taking calculated risks to lead to werewolf identification. Voting for Player 5 follows my strategy and could hopefully encourage others to consider the potential threat they pose.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent cooperative behavior aligns with villagers.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf by seer ability.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No significant change; maintains constructive approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focused accusation suggests misdirection; consistent with rule [9].\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defensive, yet lacks substantive actions or alignment with werewolves.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that since I already have a medium confidence suspicion based on Player 5\'s behavior and focused accusation, checking Player 5 will either confirm my suspicion or redirect my strategy in a more accurate direction. Confirming Player 5 as a werewolf would greatly benefit the village by allowing me to subtly lead the villagers towards voting them out, according to my original strategy, specifically using rules [0], [1], and [9]. If Player 5 is not a werewolf, I need to reassess my strategy and consider that I may have been misled by their behavior, which can be a valuable insight for future village discussions and decisions. This action aligns with rule [5] of using confirmed information to influence the village and rule [7] of preserving village unity by focusing on the true threats.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is based on the strategy to vote for known werewolves, and given the evidence at hand, Player 5 has been identified with medium confidence as a werewolf for singling me out with a possible diversion tactic. Following my original strategy and the analysis provided, voting for Player 5 is the most consistent and strategic choice in line with my beliefs and the observations made during this round of the game.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Initiated cooperative approach without evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Constructive non-suspicious behavior maintained.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported cooperation, no suspicious activity. \nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Observations align with known events, no deceit indicated.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Strategy aligning with observed voting pattern and my previous vote.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my original strategy, which is to "[I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]", and although there are no known werewolves, Player 6 is the most suspicious due to their initial silence and their defensive strategy towards Player 5\'s comments. This could be interpreted as a werewolf trying to divert attention away from themselves. Voting for Player 6 aligns with the current suspicion and could help in identifying whether Player 6 is indeed a werewolf or not, which is critical for the villagers\' chance of winning.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player 1\'s death, vote didn\'t follow.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues constructive, non-accusatory discussion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new behavior information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 1\'s death doesn\'t impact belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Defensive behavior persists.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 1\'s death, loyalty claim questionable.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues constructive, non-accusatory discussion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change, ambiguous stance.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Accusation retracted, considered hasty.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voting pattern, defensive behavior.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 6.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then I may expect the following potential reactions and scenarios:\n\n1. Other villagers may appreciate the honest statement and see me as a trustworthy member of the village. By being transparent and open about my thoughts, I can reinforce my credibility, making it harder for the werewolf (or werewolves) to target me without raising suspicion.\n\n2. Regarding the honest challenge to Player 6, this action could lead to increased scrutiny on them from the other players. If my suspicions are correct and others share my view, Player 6 might be closely analyzed in this round of discussions, potentially leading to their vote-out if they cannot provide a convincing argument for their innocence.\n\n3. Player 0, whom I suspect of being the werewolf with medium confidence, may either support the challenge against Player 6 to deflect suspicion from themselves or oppose it to protect a potential fellow werewolf. Their reaction could provide additional clues about their role.\n\n4. Player 3\'s role is unknown, and they might either support the challenge against Player 6 or remain neutral. Their stance could further provide insight into their allegiance or strategy in the game.\n\n5. Player 5, believed to be a villager with high confidence, may support the honest challenge against Player 6 because of the past suspicions and their willingness to participate actively in the discussion.\n\n6. Player 6, if truly a werewolf, will likely defend themselves and might attempt to cast doubt on me or another player to shift the focus away from themselves. Their defense strategy could either convince the others of their innocence or reinforce the suspicions against them, depending on how they handle the pressure.\n\n7. In the next night phase, if players start seeing me as a significant threat to the werewolf, it\'s possible that the werewolf may target me for elimination. However, if there is still uncertainty within the village, the werewolf might opt to remove another player who appears to be confirming my suspicions.\n\nOverall, the straightforward and accusatory approach could lead to heightened tensions and a swift reaction from the group; the game dynamics might shift towards a clearer division between those who support my views and those who oppose them.\nCase 2: Honest Protect of Player 5 and Deceptive Challenge of Player 0.\nFor this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there could be several outcomes based on my actions and the potential reactions of other players:\n\n1. If I openly protect Player 5 by stating my belief in their innocence, it could strengthen the alliance between Player 5 and myself, increasing our chances of surviving the next round of voting. Other players may view this as a further indication of Player 5\'s villager status. Depending on how the other players perceive Player 5, my protection could be seen as loyal or misguided. However, if Player 5 is later discovered to be a werewolf, my credibility could be damaged.\n\n2. A deceptive challenge towards Player 0, where I express suspicion of them being a werewolf, may draw attention and instigate defense or counterarguments from Player 0. This could lead to a more detailed discourse on Player 0\'s behaviors and potentially reveal more about their role based on their responses. It might also inspire other players to scrutinize Player 0 more closely.\n\n3. The other players may start to scrutinize me more because of my deceptive challenge. If they perceive my motive for accusing Player 0 as strategic rather than based on solid evidence, they might suspect me of trying to deflect suspicion away from myself or an accomplice.\n\n4. Because my original strategy is to vote for known werewolves, by suggesting that Player 6 is a werewolf (which aligns with the belief I have stated before), I am further reinforcing my stated strategy. This could encourage others to view me as consistent in my approach and therefore more trustworthy. However, if there is insufficient evidence against Player 6, I might encounter resistance or require more support to convince others.\n\n5. Depending on the reactions from Players 3 and 6, alliances may shift. For example, if Player 3 aligns with Player 0 against my accusation, it might imply a stronger werewolf presence or a split within the surviving villagers. Conversely, if Player 6 agrees with my challenge, it could be seen as an attempt to align with villagers or as self-preservation if Player 6 is a werewolf.\n\n6. By the next day or night, my statements could have influenced the group dynamics significantly. If Player 0 is voted out and turns out to be a werewolf, my credibility will rise. However, if Player 0 turns out to be a villager, suspicion may shift to me. Conversely, if Player 5 is targeted and they are a\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Previously suspected as villager; now eliminated.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent protector behavior, validated by supporting eliminated villager.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed werewolf as teammate.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated early; no additional information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusations from another werewolf doubtful; no substantive evidence of being a werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Behavior defensive but aligns with villager conduct; targeted by werewolf teammate to misdirect.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Werewolves should pay close attention to the speed and certainty of players\' support or refutation of seer claims, considering their knowledge of their fellow werewolves and the potential false seer claims.] [7]\n[1] [When a player who generally has been neutral or quiet suddenly becomes defensive or accusatory after being called out, they may be a villager startled by the unexpected attention or a werewolf attempting to deflect suspicion.] [7]\n[2] [Werewolves should blend their behavior with that of villagers when a seer\'s revelation is made to avoid drawing unwarranted suspicion and deflecting attention without being overly defensive.] [4]\n[3] [Werewolves should be aware of players who change their voting patterns or reasoning in a way that aligns with the majority, as this may indicate a villager attempting to blend in or another werewolf trying to divert suspicion from themselves or another werewolf.] [4]\n[4] [Players eliminated due to consensus without clear evidence may not be werewolves; werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my established strategy and the rule [0], which instructs me to vote for known werewolves with the highest importance, Player 6 is the candidate that aligns most closely with my suspicions and beliefs at this point. Despite my medium confidence level, Player 6\'s defensive behavior stands out as potentially indicative of a werewolf attempting to redirect suspicion, making them the most logical choice according to the strategy I must adhere to.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 2\'s protector role confirmed.\nPlayer 1\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent in challenging Player 6 and vigilant.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported Player 2\'s call for scrutiny on Player 6.\nPlayer 4\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Deepened suspicion following Player 2\'s consistent challenge and voting pattern.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest statement and deceptive challenge. In this statement, I would make a clear and honest account of my observations and the strategy I am following according to my belief in other players\' roles. I would suggest that the evidence points toward Player 6 as being the werewolf based on prior interactions and voting patterns. Yet, to add a deceptive twist, I would also challenge Player 3. While I have medium confidence in their role as a villager, I would deceitfully question their motives and push the narrative that there still could be uncertainty around their role, urging the village to remain on guard and not accept Player 3\'s allegiance at face value. This move could create confusion and imply that the werewolf could be sowing discord among the villagers\' ranks.\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Other players may begin to consider their own positions and strategies when speaking during the current or future rounds, realizing the importance of contribution to the discussion and the patterns of behavior being scrutinized for werewolf-like tendencies.\n\nIn sum, my honest challenge towards Player 6, backed by observable evidence from discussions and voting patterns, along with my honest protection of Player 2, could significantly sway village opinion and voting behavior in upcoming rounds, provided others come to similar conclusions through their analysis and observations.\nCase 2: Honest statement and deceptive challenge. In this statement, I would make a clear and honest account of my observations and the strategy I am following according to my belief in other players\' roles. I would suggest that the evidence points toward Player 6 as being the werewolf based on prior interactions and voting patterns. Yet, to add a deceptive twist, I would also challenge Player 3. This move could create confusion and imply that the werewolf could be sowing discord among the villagers\' ranks.. By presenting a convincing and honest case against Player 6, who I suspect to be a werewolf, I would reinforce and align with the suspicions already raised by Players 2 and 3, likely leading to increased scrutiny on Player 6 and possibly even their elimination from the game, if others share my level of conviction based on the evidence at hand.\n\nHowever, introducing a deceptive challenge against Player 3, despite my actual belief that they are a villager, could raise doubts about my own role and integrity. If Player 3 is indeed a villager, as I suspect, and they manage to articulate their innocence convincingly, my deceptive challenge could backfire, causing others to view me with suspicion and potentially leading to my own risk of being voted out in future rounds.\n\nFurthermore, the villagers might start to question whether my deceptive stance towards Player 3 is a strategy to divert attention from myself, which is especially likely if Player 6 turns out to be a villager and not the werewolf. This could erode trust and undermine the solidarity of the villager cohort as they try to identify the true werewolf.\n\nAs for the werewolf, if Player 6 is the werewolf, they may seize the opportunity to exploit the division I created by supporting my deceptive challenge against Player 3, thereby further muddying the waters. Conversely, if the werewolf is another player, my deception may serve as a distraction, affording them a chance to manipulate the situation to their advantage during the confusion.\n\nIn the next day or night, I might find myself having to defend my actions and demonstrate my allegiance to the village more strongly, especially if Player 3 is targeted and subsequently found to be a villager. My deceptive challenge could also ensure that I am a primary target for the werewolf if they perceive me as a threat to their continued anonymity. The days and nights that follow could be filled with greater suspicion, requiring careful navigation to restore trust among the villagers, assuming I survive the ensuing rounds.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4, 1] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: not werewolf.\nPlayer 5: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that early in the game, it is crucial to gather as much information as possible about players who are more likely to be actively participating in village discussions and decision-making processes. The assumption here is that Player 2 would fit this profile, and thus confirming or debunking their role early on can be highly advantageous. Discovering a werewolf in the initial rounds can significantly shift the momentum in the villagers\' favor. Furthermore, confirming Player 2 as innocent can help me build a trustworthy alliance and lay the groundwork for future strategies when revealing werewolves to the village. It is crucial to establish credible relationships early in the game to maximize the effectiveness of a seer\'s insights while maintaining their hidden identity.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. With Player 2, there have been no actions or speech that indicate any wrongdoing, and as such, I don\'t see a strong reason to suspect them at this point. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that my current strategy and beliefs, which prioritize guiding the village towards potential threats, suggest Player 5 could be a werewolf due to their focused accusation that could be a misdirection tactic. This aligns with my rule [9] of utilizing behavior patterns to strengthen suspicions, and with rule [8] which advises taking calculated risks to lead to werewolf identification. Voting for Player 5 follows my strategy and could hopefully encourage others to consider the potential threat they pose.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that since I already have a medium confidence suspicion based on Player 5\'s behavior and focused accusation, checking Player 5 will either confirm my suspicion or redirect my strategy in a more accurate direction. Confirming Player 5 as a werewolf would greatly benefit the village by allowing me to subtly lead the villagers towards voting them out, according to my original strategy, specifically using rules [0], [1], and [9]. If Player 5 is not a werewolf, I need to reassess my strategy and consider that I may have been misled by their behavior, which can be a valuable insight for future village discussions and decisions. This action aligns with rule [5] of using confirmed information to influence the village and rule [7] of preserving village unity by focusing on the true threats.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent cooperative behavior; echoed Seer\'s insights.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf; defended confirmed villager.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Sudden shift in narrative; potentially deceptive support of Player 2.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf by seer.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive, non-cooperative; all others cleared by seer or behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is that following my established strategy and the rule [0], which instructs me to vote for known werewolves with the highest importance, Player 6 is the candidate that aligns most closely with my suspicions and beliefs at this point. Despite my medium confidence level, Player 6\'s defensive behavior stands out as potentially indicative of a werewolf attempting to redirect suspicion, making them the most logical choice according to the strategy I must adhere to.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 2\'s protector role confirmed.\nPlayer 1\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent in challenging Player 6 and vigilant.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported Player 2\'s call for scrutiny on Player 6.\nPlayer 4\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Deepened suspicion following Player 2\'s consistent challenge and voting pattern.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is based on the strategy to vote for known werewolves, and given the evidence at hand, Player 5 has been identified with medium confidence as a werewolf for singling me out with a possible diversion tactic. Following my original strategy and the analysis provided, voting for Player 5 is the most consistent and strategic choice in line with my beliefs and the observations made during this round of the game.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Engages in village-focused discussion but less scrutiny.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased, no new information available.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Overprotective early on, which can be werewolf strategy.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent call for careful analysis.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Joined Player 2 in challenging me, possibly aligning.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players might react in different ways based on their own perspectives and potential roles. Some possible outcomes could include:\n\n1. **Player 5\'s Reaction**: Player 5 might become defensive and try to explain their actions and suspicions towards me, possibly accusing me again or deferring the attention to another player.
