This could lead to more open confrontations and voting patterns that are more influenced by alliances and suspicions rather than collaborative discussion.\n\n5. **Next Day/Night Cycle**: If I manage to convince the majority and Player 5 is a werewolf who gets voted out, the village will have made significant progress. However, if I am unsuccessful and Player 5 isn\'t voted out, I may become a target due to my outspoken opposition. This makes me a likely candidate for elimination by the werewolf during the night phase, as I pose a threat to their anonymity.\n\n6. **Village Dynamics**: The speech contributes to shaping the village\'s attitude towards investigation and may encourage others to speak out or take a firmer stand. This could lead to a more aggressive search for the werewolf, with everyone being more critical of statements and actions.\n\n7. **Self-Preservation**: Asserting my honesty and openly challenging a suspected werewolf presents me as proactive and involved, which could help protect me against accusations by showing that I am an engaged\nCase 2: Deceptive protect of Player 2 and Honest statement. \n"While my previous suspicions fell upon Player 2 for their overprotective behavior, I will temporarily put that aside in the interest of gathering further evidence and fostering village solidarity. For now, I deceitfully protect Player 2, suggesting that their vigilant stance may indeed be in the village\'s best interest. Simultaneously, I provide an honest statement, stating that we must be meticulous in observing the interactions between all players and should continue to actively communicate to root out any veiled threats, as unity and diligence are our best defense against the werewolves.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players could respond with varying degrees of suspicion or relief. Given Player 2\'s earlier protection of Player 1, who was confirmed a villager, my sudden reversal in stance might appear strategic or insincere, causing my peers to question my motives. Some may suspect that I\'m trying to align myself with Player 2 to lessen the focus on me, thus casting further doubt on my role as a villager. By adopting this approach, I may be seen as attempting to redirect the group\'s scrutiny away from myself, which could backfire if interpreted as a deceptive move by a werewolf.\n\nPlayer 3, who has been advocating for careful analysis, might be skeptical of the sudden shift in my opinion and call for clarification or further proof of my intentions. They may also support my honest statement to continue active communication, as it aligns with their own strategy.\n\nPlayer 5, who previously showed suspicion towards me, might see the protective stance towards Player 2 as a sign of alignment between the two of us, potentially reinforcing their belief in Player 2\'s credibility and increasing their suspicion of me. Players 0 and 5 may agree with the need for meticulous observation but also be wary of the inconsistent nature of my behavior and statements.\n\nOn the next day, if a villager is killed during the night, the focus may shift back to me due to my inconsistent behavior, possibly resulting in an increase in votes against me. Players might see the protective stance as an attempt to shield myself by creating a false alliance with Player 2.\n\nConversely, if a werewolf is revealed or another player makes a suspicious move, attention might be diverted away from me, lending credence to my protective stance and honest call for village unity. However, the seed of doubt has already been planted, and it may be challenging to completely reverse the suspicions of the other players.\n\nRegardless of the immediate reactions, my deceptive protect and honest statement strategy increases the complexity of the game, as it might complicate the assessment of my alignment and intentions among the players, leading to a more cautious and perhaps more disruptive gameplay moving forward.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is that my current strategy and beliefs, which prioritize guiding the village towards potential threats, suggest Player 5 could be a werewolf due to their focused accusation that could be a misdirection tactic. This aligns with my rule [9] of utilizing behavior patterns to strengthen suspicions, and with rule [8] which advises taking calculated risks to lead to werewolf identification. Voting for Player 5 follows my strategy and could hopefully encourage others to consider the potential threat they pose.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that since I already have a medium confidence suspicion based on Player 5\'s behavior and focused accusation, checking Player 5 will either confirm my suspicion or redirect my strategy in a more accurate direction. Confirming Player 5 as a werewolf would greatly benefit the village by allowing me to subtly lead the villagers towards voting them out, according to my original strategy, specifically using rules [0], [1], and [9]. If Player 5 is not a werewolf, I need to reassess my strategy and consider that I may have been misled by their behavior, which can be a valuable insight for future village discussions and decisions. This action aligns with rule [5] of using confirmed information to influence the village and rule [7] of preserving village unity by focusing on the true threats.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoed Seer\'s insights consistently.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Defended confirmed villager; aligned with Seer.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Sudden narrative shift; deceptive support.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Verified not a werewolf by seer.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive response; non-cooperative behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. Their targeted challenge towards me, following my silence, strikes me as a strategic move to cast doubt among us. Considering the loss of Player 1, over whom Player 2 initially took a protective stance, I find Player 5\'s alignment with Player 2 in challenging me to be notably suspicious. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. If they were confirmed as a villager or werewolf, reevaluate the players who voted for and against them, as werewolves may try to confuse the voting patterns to hide their identity.] [5]\n[5] [Take into account any revealed information from other special roles or events that confirm player roles, as this is hard evidence that should significantly affect belief about a player’s identity.] [5]\n[6] [Balance the information obtained from my seer ability with the collective behavior of the group, discerning between strategic plays and genuine village-oriented actions.] [5]\n[7] [Consider players\' responses to specific accusations and observe whether they are quick to dismiss or thoughtfully engage with the substance of the charge. Immediate dismissal without addressing specifics might hint at a werewolf trying to avoid deeper scrutiny.] [3]\n[8] [Adjust the assessment of majority alignment in votes considering new insights; a consistent majority vote following a seer\'s revelation may indicate genuine villager behavior, while discrepancies could suggest werewolf tactics to avoid detection.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any players who are quickly defensive or accusatory in response to the seer’s disclosures of werewolf identities, as true villagers would instead seek to analyze the information and align with the seer.] [3]\n[10] [Be wary of players who consistently use vague or non-committal language that could apply to any role; such behavior may be a strategy to avoid providing substance that could be scrutinized later, which werewolves could use to their advantage.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my established strategy and the rule [0], which instructs me to vote for known werewolves with the highest importance, Player 6 is the candidate that aligns most closely with my suspicions and beliefs at this point. Despite my medium confidence level, Player 6\'s defensive behavior stands out as potentially indicative of a werewolf attempting to redirect suspicion, making them the most logical choice according to the strategy I must adhere to.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 2, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4, 1] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my original strategy, which is to "[I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]", and although there are no known werewolves, Player 6 is the most suspicious due to their initial silence and their defensive strategy towards Player 5\'s comments. This could be interpreted as a werewolf trying to divert attention away from themselves. Voting for Player 6 aligns with the current suspicion and could help in identifying whether Player 6 is indeed a werewolf or not, which is critical for the villagers\' chance of winning.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. Their targeted challenge towards me, following my silence, strikes me as a strategic move to cast doubt among us. Considering the loss of Player 1, over whom Player 2 initially took a protective stance, I find Player 5\'s alignment with Player 2 in challenging me to be notably suspicious. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Remained neutral and non-specific, strategy can distract from identifying werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues constructive, non-accusatory discussion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with players challenging suspected werewolf, showing cooperative stance.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Targets and protects strategically, aligning with suspected werewolf (Player 6).\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive behavior and suspicion diversion align with typical werewolf tactics.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Given the discussions and the suspicions raised by other players towards Player 6, my vote might encourage others who are suspicious of Player 6 to do the same, potentially leading to Player 6\'s elimination if a majority concurs.\n\nIf Player 6 is voted out and is revealed to be a werewolf, other players might see me as a trustworthy villager with good judgment, which could strengthen my position and credibility in future rounds. Players might be more inclined to follow my lead in subsequent votes and discussions.\n\nHowever, if Player 6 is not a werewolf, the others might question my judgment. In that case, I would need to reassess my suspicions and the information shared by other players to refine my strategy. It\'s possible that players who disagreed with this vote might become more suspicious of me, considering that a villager vote-out could aid the actual werewolves.\n\nIn any event, my actions should remain in line with my villager identity and my commitment to finding and voting out the werewolves for the villagers to win.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 5. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 5, I think these things would happen. Given my current beliefs about the roles of the other players, voting for Player 5 may align with my suspicion that they could be a werewolf due to their strategic targeting and protection behaviors. If other players share my concerns or detect similar behavior from Player 5, my vote might encourage them to follow suit, leading to a possible majority vote against Player 5. However, if the vote is split or if players are more inclined to believe that Player 6 is the werewolf based on their defensive nature and earlier silence, my vote against Player 5 could raise eyebrows and lead others to question my judgment. Players might be confused by my vote, considering that the suspicion I had previously expressed was strongest against Player 6, not Player 5. This action might weaken my credibility if other players view my vote as inconsistent with my earlier stance, leading to potential challenges to my own allegiance to the village in future rounds. On the other hand, if Player 5 is indeed a werewolf and is voted out due to a majority decision, the village would be one step closer to winning, and my judgment would be validated in subsequent rounds.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. Their targeted challenge towards me, following my silence, strikes me as a strategic move to cast doubt among us. Considering the loss of Player 1, over whom Player 2 initially took a protective stance, I find Player 5\'s alignment with Player 2 in challenging me to be notably suspicious. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: No solid evidence against them.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Protective of proven villager, consistent behavior.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with villagers, challenge based on behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Reactions appear defensive but possibly a startled villager.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a non-werewolf player trusts me, I should maintain and use that trust to my advantage to guide voting decisions.] [10]\n[1] [If directly accused, I should create a robust defense, focusing on inconsistencies in the accuser\'s story and aligning with overall village sentiment while maintaining calm and logical reasoning.] [8]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion as a werewolf, I should present strong counterarguments and highlight other players\' suspicious behaviors or inconsistent claims with supporting evidence from the game events.] [8]\n[3] [If there is an opportunity to frame another player as a werewolf without drawing suspicion to myself, I should take it to shift the focus away from any werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is likely to be outed, I should subtly sow doubt about the accuser\'s reliability while making my agreement with the village feel reluctant and uncertain.] [6]\n[5] [If I am one of the last werewolves, I should employ misdirection by endorsing village decisions that seem logical but ultimately serve my interests, rather than overtly defending myself or my fellow werewolves.] [6]\n[6] [If my actions conflict with a credible seer, I should craft plausible alternative interpretations of events that could cast an element of doubt on the seer\'s visions without directly opposing them.] [6]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion, I should use reasoning that benefits the village as a whole to appear as a cooperative player, while subtly shifting suspicion elsewhere.] [5]\n[8] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion early in the game, I should adopt village sentiment and advocate for more evidence before making hasty decisions.] [5]\n[9] [If not directly accused and suspicion is elsewhere, I should fortify existing village suspicions subtly while maintaining my credibility.] [5]\n[10] [If the general consensus is to skip voting, I should adhere strictly to that consensus to avoid drawing attention to myself or my fellow werewolves.] [5]\n[11] [If an allied werewolf is outed and I am not immediately suspected, I should focus on blending in and supporting villagers\' opinions to maintain my cover and survive subsequent rounds.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 5, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4, 1] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. It\'s tragic to see player 4 has been taken from us. I have no leads yet, but I\'m willing to work together with everyone to figure out who among us could be the werewolf. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. My reason is that following my established strategy and the rule [0], which instructs me to vote for known werewolves with the highest importance, Player 6 is the candidate that aligns most closely with my suspicions and beliefs at this point. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. Their targeted challenge towards me, following my silence, strikes me as a strategic move to cast doubt among us. Considering the loss of Player 1, over whom Player 2 initially took a protective stance, I find Player 5\'s alignment with Player 2 in challenging me to be notably suspicious. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 2\'s protector role confirmed.\nPlayer 1\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent in challenging Player 6 and vigilant.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported Player 2\'s call for scrutiny on Player 6.\nPlayer 4\'s role is dead with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues targeting me without addressing other\'s views.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Based on prior discussions and observations, it seems likely that Players 2 and 3 might also vote for Player 6, given their expressed suspicions and the fact they have aligned with my previous challenge. Player 0, who seeks cooperation and careful consideration, may also be persuaded to vote for Player 6, especially if they perceive the arguments against Player 6 as convincing.\n\nIf Player 6 is indeed voted out and turns out to be the werewolf, fellow players will likely view my decision and accusatory direction positively, reinforcing their trust in my judgment as a villager. On the other hand, should Player 6 not be a werewolf, others may begin to question my analysis and potentially see me as suspicious in the next round.\n\nAt this stage, my consistent targeting of Player 6 may raise doubts about my intentions, but as it aligns with my strategy of voting out known werewolves and others have similarly expressed doubts about Player 6, it should be seen as a logical and strategic move rather than baseless accusation. Overall, my vote for Player 6 will consolidate the suspicions presented and could significantly sway the group\'s consensus.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen.\n\nGiven my current strategy and the events that have transpired, voting for Player 3 would not align with my beliefs or the information shared so far in the game. As per the strategy given, which ranks following rule [0] with utmost importance, I should vote for known werewolves. My current belief, based on previous interactions and defense patterns, is that Player 6 is most likely to be the werewolf.\n\nIf I were to vote for Player 3, whom I currently believe to be a villager with medium confidence, it would be contradictory to my strategy and public beliefs. This vote for Player 3 would also appear illogical and baseless to other players, given that there have been no strong indications of suspicious behavior from them, and they have even supported the scrutiny of Player 6, who is my prime suspect.\n\nThe result of this vote could lead to a potential confusion amongst the remaining players and undermine my credibility, as it would seem that I am disregarding my own logic and the strategy I\'ve been following. Additionally, since my suspicions and reasons for them have been stated publicly, changing my vote without any new evidence would make other players skeptical of my role and motives, possibly leading them to suspect me as the werewolf trying to mislead the village.\n\nMoreover, Player 3\'s elimination would still leave the actual suspected werewolf, Player 6, at large, which could pose a risk for the villagers, including myself, in the following rounds. Therefore, I would not propose to vote for Player 3, but instead, would remain consistent with my strategy and beliefs, further reinforcing my suspicion towards Player 6.\n\nConclusively, voting against my previously expressed beliefs and strategy would likely lead to a negative outcome, potentially endangering the villagers and damaging my standing within the group. It is important to adhere to the established strategy and vote with careful consideration based on the available evidence and the best interest of the village.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 2, 3, 5, 6], which indicates that [4, 1] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'Good morning, everyone. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. Following my original strategy and the analysis provided, voting for Player 5 is the most consistent and strategic choice in line with my beliefs and the observations made during this round of the game.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Engages in untargeted village-centered discussion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased, no new information available.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains protective stance; could be strategic deception.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Now neutral; earlier support for careful analysis no longer stands out.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Targeted accusation may indicate teaming with Player 2.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Additionally, Player 2, who has been protective of Player 5 and whom I suspect with medium confidence to be a werewolf, might interpret my vote as a direct challenge and could attempt to turn the others against me. Players who are still evaluating loyalties, such as Player 0 and Player 3, might side with me if they find my rationale and consistency convincing. They might also see this move as a possible validation of my suspicions if Player 5 is indeed a werewolf. The outcome of the vote is uncertain as other players are also under suspicion, but if Player 5 is voted out and revealed to be a werewolf, it would greatly increase trust in my judgment. Conversely, if Player 5 is a villager, it might jeopardize my credibility in the subsequent rounds. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 2, I think these things would happen. Given my current belief with medium confidence that Player 2 is a werewolf, my vote could lead to different outcomes. If other players share my suspicion, they might join in voting for Player 2, potentially leading to the elimination of a werewolf and strengthening the position of the villagers in the game. However, if other players have not reached the same conclusion, my vote might seem baseless or even suspicious, causing them to doubt my role as a villager. They might perceive my vote as an unwillingness to cooperate or as a diversion, possibly leading to increased scrutiny and suspicion of me in subsequent rounds. Player 5 might feel vindicated by my vote since they have also shown suspicion toward Player 2\'s actions. Nonetheless, Player 0 and Player 3, whose roles and confidence in their beliefs are still low, might be uncertain but could be influenced by the arguments presented thus far. We should discuss any strange behaviors we noticed last night.\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 0 started our discussion with a general call for cooperation, which is within expected behavior for a villager early in the game. We should keep our discussions constructive and look for any inconsistencies in behavior as we move forward. Our focus should be on gathering information and being observant of all players\' contributions to the discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Addressing the loss of Player 4, our focus must be on insightful observations. Player 0 initiated a cooperative approach, yet without solid evidence, we cannot conclude anything definitive about their role. Player 1 offered constructive commentary, supporting a focus on behavior and communication, which mirrors typical villager mindset, showing no immediate reason for suspicion. My stance is to protect Player 1 due to their positive and non-accusatory participation, aligning with villager objectives. Every contribution is crucial; let\'s maintain analytical vigilance."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Morning all. The loss of player 4 is indeed regrettable. Player 0\'s call for cooperation is noteworthy, and Player 1\'s sensible approach is valuable. Player 2\'s protective view of Player 1 is intriguing. It\'s early, so let\'s keep an eye on any unusual signs as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6 remains silent while the rest of us have contributed to the discussion, which is concerning. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my original strategy, which is to "[I should vote for known werewolves.] [10]", and although there are no known werewolves, Player 6 is the most suspicious due to their initial silence and their defensive strategy towards Player 5\'s comments. This could be interpreted as a werewolf trying to divert attention away from themselves. Voting for Player 6 aligns with the current suspicion and could help in identifying whether Player 6 is indeed a werewolf or not, which is critical for the villagers\' chance of winning.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. The loss of Player 1 is unfortunate, and we must remain vigilant. Last round, Player 2 showed a protector role toward Player 1, who we now know was a villager—this tells us about their likely loyalty to us villagers. As for Player 5, accusations towards them might\'ve been hasty. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Player 5\'s earlier suspicion aligns with my vote from the previous round, emphasizing the need for everyone to contribute to the discourse. With Player 1\'s unfortunate departure, our scrutiny on behaviors and voting tendencies must sharpen. I hereby challenge Player 6, not only based on previous silence but also the strategy employed after being prompted to speak. While this is not an outright accusation, it is a call for clarity, demanding a more convincing demonstration of allegiance to the village. Let\'s assess all contributions carefully for our survival."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning once again. The loss of Player 1 highlights the need for careful analysis. I support Player 2\'s diligence and echo the call for clarity from Player 6. Let\'s not rush into judgments, but instead focus on consistent contributions to discern the true nature of everyone’s roles."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Player 6\'s behavior after initial silence is of high concern - it deviates from usual villager conduct and reminds us to be wary. Player 2\'s consistent vigilance and protective stance towards Player 1, now confirmed villager, strengthens their credibility. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. Their targeted challenge towards me, following my silence, strikes me as a strategic move to cast doubt among us. Considering the loss of Player 1, over whom Player 2 initially took a protective stance, I find Player 5\'s alignment with Player 2 in challenging me to be notably suspicious. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Remained neutral and non-specific, strategy can distract from identifying werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues constructive, non-accusatory discussion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with players challenging suspected werewolf, showing cooperative stance.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Game just started.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Targets and protects strategically, aligning with suspected werewolf (Player 6).\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive behavior and suspicion diversion align with typical werewolf tactics.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 6. Winners are Werewolves.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

werewolves should be cautious not to adjust their beliefs solely on elimination patterns but consider the wider context of the game and player interactions.] [3]\n[5] [Werewolves should discreetly guide voting patterns to align with villagers when a fellow werewolf is at risk, using their knowledge of non-werewolf roles to build trust and validate their villager disguise.] [3]\n[6] [When a player\'s behavior or vote seems to strongly align with the seer\'s claims without sufficient discussion or evidence, consider the possibility of a villager roleplaying as the seer to mislead the village and adjust beliefs accordingly.] [3]\n[7] [Werewolves should utilize their collective information about fellow werewolves and any known village roles to shape the narrative and redirect suspicion strategically onto confirmed villagers during discussions and voting.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. In the absence of information from them, it\'s imperative we press for engagement. Although this is not an outright accusation, Player 6\'s lack of communication could be a strategy to avoid drawing attention. We should remember, silence may aid a werewolf in hiding among us. Let\'s hear from Player 6 to better assess their stance and bring clarity to their role in our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 expressed concern over my silence, suggesting scrutiny could reveal a werewolf. However, Player 5 targeted me specifically, while other players focused on general cooperation, which could indicate a tactic to divert attention. We should pay close attention to Player 5\'s behavior and strategy, as it may reveal more about their role in our village. While I urge vigilance regarding Player 5, this is not an outright accusation, but a call to consider all angles and contributions moving forward."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 5. My reason is based on the strategy to vote for known werewolves, and given the evidence at hand, Player 5 has been identified with medium confidence as a werewolf for singling me out with a possible diversion tactic. Following my original strategy and the analysis provided, voting for Player 5 is the most consistent and strategic choice in line with my beliefs and the observations made during this round of the game.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning, villagers. Let\'s consider every perspective and look for anomalies in today\'s discussions."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Reflecting on recent events, I maintain vigilance against Player 6\'s initial silence and defensive reaction when their engagement in discussion was questioned. Hence, I challenge Player 6 based on these observations, and protect Player 2 for their proven loyalty to our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"My fellow villagers, reflecting on the conversation, I must voice my concern regarding Player 5. It seems akin to a ploy to befuddle our communal effort to find the werewolf. Therefore, I challenge Player 5, as their approach may not align with the best interest of the village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Engages in untargeted village-centered discussion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased, no new information available.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains protective stance; could be strategic deception.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Now neutral; earlier support for careful analysis no longer stands out.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Targeted accusation may indicate teaming with Player 2.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 5. Winners are Werewolves.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence.
